' - TAX COMMISSIONERS OF NEBRASKA The position of State Tax Commissioner was created by the Con - stitution of 1920. Prior thereto the work was performed by a secretary I to the State Board of Equalization and Assessment, the Tax Commis - sioner being made a member of the board. Those who have served as . Commissioner under the constitutional provision are: NAME COUNTY SERVED W. H. OSBORNE Custer April 25, 1921 to April 18, 1923 WM. H. SMITH Seward April 18, 1923 to Jan. 12, 1925 IT. E. WILLIAMS Hamilton Jan. 12, 1925 to Jan. 8, 1929 HARRY W. SCOTT— Lancaster Jan. 8, 1929 to Dec. 1, 1930 WE H. SMITH Seward Jan. 8, 1931 to

LETTER OF TRANSMITTAL OFFICE OF STATE TAX COMMISSIONER LINCOLN, NEBRASKA December 1, 1936. Honorable R. L. Cochran, Governor of Nebraska, Lincoln, Nebraska. My dear Governor: There is being submitted to you herewith the annual report of the State Board of Equalization and Assessment and the State Tax Com - missioner for the year 1936. The valuation of the state, as returned by the county assessors, is found to be $2,060,835,168.00, which -is an increase of approximately $30,500,000.00 over the valuation found m 1935, bat it is still one-third less than the valuation of 1929, and years prior thereto, the total for 1929 being $3,167,489,300.00. The tax rate for state purposes for the year 1936 was fixed at 1.76 mills, the lowest levy since the state began assessing at the full actual valuation of prop - erty m 1921. Nearly one-half the increase m valuation m 1936, over that re - turned m 1935, is due to the new law relating to the assessment of motor vehicles. The results of the assessment m 1935 and 1936 are quite interesting, the figures for the former year being those returned by the county assessors before the new act took effect, while the figures for the latter year are the result of the assessment under the new law. 1935 1936 Number 329,577 381,623 Valuation $27,324,829.00 $41,509,357.00 Average $ 82.91 $ 108.77 While the number listed for taxation increased 18 per cent, the taxed value increased 52 per cent. The law has resulted m a uniform assessment of motor vehicles, and m this respect, it is perhaps the one class of property that is now so assessed. The law needs some revision, however, to enable its being administered more economically.

Total ■ $2,060,835,168 1.000,000 i Intangible property valuations totaled $110,960,397, Class A repre - senting $48,059,189, while Class B represented 862,901,208. It will be observed that real estate, including both town lots and lands and improvements, represent 76.7% of the total taxable value of the state, whereas farm property which is represented by items 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, and one-half each of 8 and 9, represents 64% of the total. During the past assessment period, four group meetings were held, at which 41 counties were represented, the meetings, the dates and the attendance at each one being as follows: April 10— : Norfolk, ten counties represented. April 21 — Grand Island, seventeen counties represented. April 22 — Alliance, nine counties represented. May 1 — Tecumseh, five counties represented. Total representation, 41 counties.

STATE OF NEBRASKA In addition to the group meetings, at which problems of interest to the county and local assessors were considered, the annual state meeting was held at Holdrege March 12-13, 1936, with 65 counties represented. We also issued nine bulletins in which questions were answered and problems discussed, with which the assessors have to deal. Respectfully submitted, State Tax Commissioner.

STATE OF NEBRASKA STATEMENT NO. 4 ROLLING STOCK ASSESSMENT The rolling stock assessment of the various railroads is made by the State Board of Equalization and Assessment in accordance with Section 77-616, Compiled Statutes of Nebraska for 1929. The amount so found is divided by the total number of miles, givng the total valuation per mile, and this amount is multiplied by the number of miles in each city and village. This amount is then certified to the county clerk to be added to the assessment of terminal property which is made by the local assessor and equalized by the State Board.
